title: Spanish
text:
Spanish



I have learned a lot since I started studying Spanish at UCSB two years ago!


In addition to teaching language proficiency, the Spanish major encompasses a diverse range of subjects including linguistics, language and translation, Peninsular Spanish studies, Latin American studies, U.S. Latinx studies, and Indigenous languages and cultures of the Americas.


I had the amazing opportunity to develop my Spanish-speaking abilities while living in Madrid, Spain for a semester.


While in Madrid, I attended the Universidad de Complutense and took classes on Latin American Theater, Modern Spanish Literature, and the Spanish Short Story. Apart from just my studies, I learned a lot about Spanish culture, art, and history through experience.


Take a look at some of my photos from the trip!

Tuve una oportunidad increíble de desarrollar mis habilidades para hablar español mientras vivía en Madrid, España durante un semestre.


Durante mi estancia en Madrid, asistí a la Universidad Complutense y tomé clases de Teatro Latinoamericano, Literatura Española Actual y el Cuento Español. Aparte de mis estudios, aprendí muchas sobre la cultura, arte y historia española a través de experiencias.

title: Research
text:
I am a research assistant at UCSB, working in both the Anderegg Landscape Ecophysiology and Function (LEAF) Lab and the D’Antonio Vegetation Lab.The projects I am currently involved in focus on quantifying the physiological effects of prescribed fire on oak trees and identifying potential drivers of vegetation change in Mediterranean ecosystems. In addition to this work, I am conducting a personal research project examining the impact of bark beetles on oak woodlands after fire events.

title: Impact of Bark and Ambrosia Beetles on Varietal Oak Woodlands After Fire Events
text:
As the threat of wildfires continues to grow, many are turning to Indigenous practices of using prescribed burns to prevent megafires and promote forest health. While prescribed burns offer numerous ecological and cultural benefits, the presence of bark and ambrosia beetles can complicate these outcomes. These insects infest trees by boring beneath the bark, creating spaces to grow and reproduce. In the process, they introduce various fungi into the trees’ sapwood, which can sometimes lead to tree mortality. Since bark and ambrosia beetles tend to target stressed or dying trees, I am investigating whether prescribed burns in infested areas might inadvertently boost beetle populations, potentially increasing tree mortality.
To explore this, I am studying blue oak and coast live oak species following prescribed burns at Sedgwick Reserve, focusing on bark and ambrosia beetles species belonging to Monarthrum and Pseudopityophthorus genera. My approach combines visual surveys and pheromone trapping to quantify changes in beetle populations. This research aims to better understand how these beetles should be managed in fire-prone ecosystems.
